profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 00:34

did.unittitle: The Ole Bull Papers
did.abstract: Music and other materials by and about the Norwegian violinist and composer Ole Bull (1810-1880)

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The Papers are open to researchers by appointment. There are no restricted materials in the collection. Please contact the Special Collections staff to schedule an appointment.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Ole Bull Papers were established in the Music Library of Yale University by Patricia Bull Smith Langdon, Olea Smith-Kaland, Stephen Bartlett Smith, and Shapleigh Smith in 1989.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Ole Bull Papers are the physical property of the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University. Copyrights belong to the composers and authors, or their legal heirs and assigns.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Misc. Ms. 286, The Ole Bull Papers in the Irving S. Gilmore Music Library of Yale University.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In 4 series as follows: I. Music by Ole Bull. II. Music by others: manuscript copies. III. Music by others: printed works. IV. Miscellaneous items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Ole Bull Papers contain sketches, manuscript scores, or printed editions of 11 compositions by Bull. The Papers also hold music by other composers from Bull's personal library. Among the miscellaneous items are programs, printed works relating to Bull, and 13 manuscript receipts which document a series of concerts played by Bull in 1853 in Charleston, South Carolina.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ole Bull was born in Bergen, Norway on February 5, 1810. From an early age he showed a rare talent for the violin, and he made his solo debut in 1819. He took lessons from students of Viotti and Baillot, and also learned much from traditional Norwegian fiddlers, an influence that contributed to his unique style. Bull was interested in the design and construction of violins and bows, and by using a flatter bridge and a rounded bow, he was able to produce unusual polyphonic effects. He made many European concert tours, and he also spent a considerable amount of time in the United States, as a violinist, impresario, and promoter of an ill-fated Norwegian colony in Pennsylvania. Bull was known for his virtuosic and idiosyncratic performances, his personal charisma, and his Norwegian nationalism. (Norway was under Swedish control from 1814 to 1905.) Ole Bull died in Lysøen, Norway on August 17, 1880.

Miscellaneous items
13 manuscript receipts relating to a series of concerts played by Ole Bull in Charleston, SC.
Miscellaneous

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: 1 Autograph letter signed (photocopy) from Ole Bull, in French.
2 manuscript programs of Ole Bull's concerts. 1 in French. 1 in Russian.
1 printed program of Ole Bull's last concert in Brooklyn, May 10, 1877.
